title: Does nothing exist? Like space is a void but even a void. Is it possible to have no color, no void, no nothing? - Quora

response.answer_text: That’s an interesting question. Nothing means nothing - the absence of anything. Space is not like that. It’s teeming with energy. It’s a thing intertwined with time to create the flexible fabric of spacetime. However, we don’t know whether nothing exists because we haven’t observed it anywhere in our universe. That may sound like an oxymoron - not having observed nothing. But to me, “nothing” remains a concept only. Everywhere we look, there is only stuff. Outside of the horizon of our universe, we give up and say “there’s nothing out there.” But again, based on what?

Things exist in space. Space itself is the absence of things (between them and within them on micro-scale. )The absence of things is also called a void, i.e., no thing. Quantum physics is fond of claiming that there is no empty space. That would make the universe a solid block of “stuff” with no empty space between things. That is nonsense. Your second question doesn’t make sense. It treats a void (emptiness) as a thing.

No. Nothingness exists and thus we can not have no nothing. It is the same as saying ‘can we have non-existence?’ and i would answer the same way in that no there is no such thing as nonexistence. Yes there is nothingness but that is not the same as non-existence.

Distinguish nothing of that (there are no “z’s” in this paragraph) from nothing at all, an absolute nothing. According to physicists, there is no absolute nothing. There are vacuums. Vacuums are a case of nothing of that to an ever finer but never perfect degree. Even quantum vacuums are not nothing at all, for they seethe with virtual particles winking in and out of existence and are bathed in fields.

There is always something that is absent from a condition or space, that deserves accountability. Suggestion or supposing there would be a place that is a literal nothingness is anathema to all limits and infinites.
